discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Correct answers: A & E
Centralized logging has nothing to do with reduced CPU and memory.

A. reduces the time required to query log data across multiple hosts - it is better to search in a single place than multiple to find a root cause - Correct
B. reduces the loss of logs after a single disk failure - It will reduce the data loss if the disk belongs to the application, but this could be a problem if the disk belongs to the centralized logging and how the logging has been deployed (multiples disks maybe?)

E. provides compression and layout of log data - The compression could be done depending on the tools and storage that you will use. Also, a layout will be provided. - Correct
A, B are correct.

Selected Answer: AB
Why Not the Other Options?
C (Improves application performance by reducing CPU usage) ❌

Centralized logging focuses on log aggregation and storage, not directly on application CPU performance.
D (Improves application performance by reducing memory usage) ❌

While centralized logging reduces the burden of log storage and management on individual hosts, it does not have a significant impact on an application's memory usage.
E (Provides compression and layout of log data) ❌

While some centralized logging services might offer compression, this is not a core benefit or purpose of centralized logging.

Selected Answer: AB
I'll go with A & B.

Selected Answer: AE
A and E seem the best answers here.
A. reduces the time required to query log data across multiple hosts - it is better to search in a single place than multiple to find a root cause - Correct
B. reduces the loss of logs after a single disk failure - It will reduce the data loss if the disk belongs to the application, but this could be a problem if the disk belongs to the centralized logging and how the logging has been deployed (multiples disks maybe?) - I'm not sure about this.
C. improves application performance by reducing CPU usage - It will improve the CPU of the application, but the centralized logging will consume more CPU per application since we can specify that the log will be processed by the logging instead of being processed locally. In network devices, we can spread which logs will be processed locally and which ones will not. I'm not sure if this could be easily applied to the code as well. 
D. improves application performance by reducing memory usage - The same idea of CPU usage - I'm not either. 
E. provides compression and layout of log data - The compression could be done depending on the tools and storage that you will use. Also, a layout will be provided. - Correct

Selected Answer: AE
A and E for me. If the central logging server has one disk, then it will still fail. That is why B is IMO incorrect.

A&E looks right.
B doesn't sound correct, at least not without knowing how that "centralized" logging server is set-up (physically and logically). There's no clue to know if it has a single Disk, or Disk redundancy (although one could make the case that it would be very unlikely to set up a centralized log server without HD redundancy of some sort).

B doesn't make sense. Because also a logserver can fail and loss data. 
So A&E make most sense.

Selected Answer: AE
IMO this should be A & E.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct as from official Study guide page 112: "Logs become distributed as well, and now it's unfeasible to connect to each component...The solution to this problem is to send all the generated logs to an external, centralized place...where all the logs are easily found."
A and E

comments.content: Not sure what centralized logging service has to do with reducing the CPU of the app.

discussion.content: IMO A and C are corect.

choices.B: reduces the loss of logs after a single disk failure
choices.D: improves application performance by reducing memory usage
choices.C: improves application performance by reducing CPU usage
choices.E: provides compression and layout of log data
choices.A: reduces the time required to query log data across multiple hosts

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of using a centralized logging service? (Choose two.)

A team of developers created their own CA and started signing certificates for all of their IoT devices.
Which action will make the browser accept these certificates?

choices.A: Install a TLS instead of SSL certificate on the IoT devices.
choices.D: Enable HTTPS or port 443 on the browser.
choices.C: Preload the developer CA on the trusted CA list of the browser.

discussion.content: I think answer should be C. Own CA should be in CRL

Selected Answer: C
the browser needs an CA to trust cert, otherwise there would be a warning.

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer: C
the browser needs an CA to trust cert, otherwise there would be a warning.

Or use public signed certificates.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct:

To obtain and activate its identity certificate, the system’s (website) owner needs to enroll with the CA first. Here’s the process:
 - The resource’s RSA key pair (public and private) is generated.
 - A certificate signing request (CSR) containing identity information and the public key is delivered to a CA. Identity details can include data such as the system name, the organization to which the system belongs, and location information.
 - The CA validates the request.
 - The CA generates the system’s certificate, which contains these (or more) fields, as per the X.509 standard:
- Serial Number, Subject, Public Key, Key Usage, Not Before and Not After, Issuer, Signature Algorithm, Signature.
- The certificate is delivered back and installed on a system.

Selected Answer: C
Voting for C. I assume that the IoT device is accessible over HTTPS and that the manufacturer wants to access from a client.

comments.content: It cannot be A as TLS and SSL certificates are the same thing. A certificate can be used for both TLS and SSL. Note: I'm not saying that TLS and SSL are the same thing.

discussion.content:
IoT devices most likely have not a browser at all, so C does not sound good. But A sounds bad as well. A or C but it depends on exact wording.
C is better

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
An engineer must access multiple bots that are running in an internal infrastructure. A different HTTPS URL is required for each bot. The infrastructure has just one public IP address and a Linux server with Apache installed. Drag and drop the actions from the left into the order of steps on the right to enable access to the bots inside. Not all options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
1. Enable a reverse proxy server on Apache
2. Set up vhost files
3. install LetsEncrypt on apache server

comments.content:
reference URL no longer available, returns 404

Here's a replacement for reference purposes: https://bendellar.com/apache-as-reverse-proxy-for-letsencrypt-free-https-certificates/

discussion.content:
1. Enable ReverseProxy on Apache Server
2. Setup virtualhosts on Apache Server
3. Install LetsEncrypt on Apache Server 

https://acabey.xyz/blog/posts/6-8-17/

To allow access to multiple bots each with a unique HTTPS URL through a single public IP address using Apache, here’s the correct order of steps:

Configure “Let’s Encrypt” on the Apache server.
This step sets up HTTPS for secure access to the Apache server. Let's Encrypt will provide SSL certificates, allowing secure HTTPS connections.

Configure Apache virtual hosts.
Virtual hosts allow Apache to serve different applications or services on the same IP but with different URLs (or subdomains), each routing to a specific bot.

Enable a reverse proxy in Apache.
The reverse proxy in Apache will direct incoming requests to the appropriate bot server based on the URL or subdomain, allowing internal bots to be accessed from outside.

Trying to figure out, does the order matters here ?
Mean from my side, i would definitely do stuff with certs first, after that changed config of virtualhosts + proxypass at the same time and restart apache. so may be: 1) install letsencrypt 2) configure vhosts 3) configure reverse proxy ?

Correct answers: 
1. Enable ReverseProxy on Apache Server
2. Setup virtualhosts on Apache Server
3. Install LetsEncrypt on Apache Server 

https://acabey.xyz/blog/posts/6-8-17/

comments.content:
Sorry.
3. Configure Let's Encrypt on the Apache server

discussion.content:
1. Enable a reverse proxy in Apache
2. Configure Apache virtual host
3. Configure Let's Encrypt on the bot servers

https://acabey.xyz/blog/posts/6-8-17/

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of using distributed log collectors? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Sorry, I muss correct me. I mean best is B&C.

Selected Answer: BE
B and E
Keyword here is distributed. C has nothing to do with it.

Selected Answer: BC
B&C makes sense

Selected Answer: CD
Why not CD ? elk for example. ton of logging plugins (C). logs could be modified/filtered/processed before exporting (D)

Selected Answer: BE
the question states 'benefits' not features

Selected Answer: CE
C: provides flexibility due to a wide range of plugins and accepted log formats... the distributed server can then translate/reformat the logs it received before sending to the centralized logging repository, so the centralized repository has all logs in a common format

E: the distributed server can receive the incoming logs within a remote data center or edge data center or geography, then continually retry transmitting to the centralized logging repository until network connectivity to the centralized logging repository is restored

Selected Answer: BC
BC..........

Selected Answer: AB
giving that the key word is "distributed", I would go with A & B.

A. supports multiple transport protocols such as TCP/UDP - This could be done using TCP or UDP - correct - its a plus

B. improves performance and reduces resource consumption - It will improve the CPU of the application, but centralized logging will consume more CPU per application - correct just because they specified "distributed"

I like C but nothing to do with Distributed.

comments.content:
Or A & C 
With distrubuted logging application maybe uses more resources than local logging.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B&C seems best to me.

About performance:
"The utility of logs, unfortunately, ends right there. While log generation might be easy, the performance idiosyncrasies of various popular logging libraries leave a lot to be desired. Most performant logging libraries allocate very little, if any, and are extremely fast. However, the default logging libraries of many languages and frameworks are not the cream of the crop, which means the application as a whole becomes susceptible to suboptimal performance due to the overhead of logging. "

Selected Answer: AC
A and C seem more correct than the others.
A. supports multiple transport protocols such as TCP/UDP - This could be done using TCP or UDP - correct
B. improves performance and reduces resource consumption - It will improve the CPU of the application, but centralized logging will consume more CPU per application since we can specify that the log will be processed by the logging instead of being processed locally. In network devices, we can spread which logs will be processed locally and which ones will not. I'm not sure if this could be easily applied to the code. 
C. provides flexibility due to a wide range of plugins and accepted log formats - It is correct since we can use the ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) stack.
 D. enables extension of logs with fields and export to backend systems - Incorrect 
 E. buffers and resends data when the network is unavailable - We can establish a limit for network devices to buffer their logs and discard them if this limit is reached, but I'm not sure if this could be applied here.
All seem a bit off, even B. distributing the log collection still uses resources, and probably even more. 1 server with the power of 10 distributed servers has less overhead.
The only option that in indisputably correct is B. Everything else depends so much on what is the actual environment and the configs in use on devices and log collectors.
I think it's A&C!
Not sure but B&E seems the correct answer

choices.E: buffers and resends data when the network is unavailable
choices.C: provides flexibility due to a wide range of plugins and accepted log formats
choices.D: enables extension of logs with fields and export to backend systems
choices.B: improves performance and reduces resource consumption
choices.A: supports multiple transport protocols such as TCP/UDP
